Been wanting to play this game for the longest time, and just now got to play it. It met my expectations and beyond: the story is fantastic even when driven by just two (visible) characters, it makes you think out of the box, the gameplay with portals is particular and fabulous, and the fact that the main character is a woman... Well, that almost bought me by itself, because I've been starving for some female protagonists in anything other than MMO's and Pokémon. 

The only problem: it started staggering here and there from mid-game on and it was quite annoying, but otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed it (and for someone who flees desperately from anything first-person, that's quite a feat).

Totally recommended.
Pura lógica, muito bom

Portal is an intriguing puzzle game where you make use of portals (Obviously) to solve puzzles. You must also use energy orbs (The same ones found in Half-Life 2 and its episodes) and weighted cubes to open doorways, activate switches, and deactivate turrets (By knocking them over, just like in Half-Life 2 and its episodes. See the connection yet?) This game is recommended for puzzle fans, action fans, Valve fans, and more. Portal is, to put it simply, one of the reasons why Valve is one of the best game companies out there. Give it a try. You won't be disappointed.

A definate "must own" for any computer gamer's library. Portal is an immersive first-person puzzle game filled challenges that will be both fun and challenging. That combined with GLaDOS's passive-aggressive taunts definately make this game worth the time and money. The first-person point of view is definately a unique way to go about solving puzzles and really separates Portal from any other puzzle game. My only hang-up was that I thought it should've been a little longer, however it did wrap up nicely and still left me satisfied. Also there are community tests and a sequel if you where left hungry for more.
Overall this game is an instant classic and I definately recommend it to everyone who owns a computer. 
9/10

Relatively short game, but well worth the play! There were times that got really frustrating, because you have to stop and really think. It gets difficult at points, but usually it just involves trying to think out of the box... and replaying parts until you 'get' them. Don't look up spoilers, or guides, unless you have to! If you do, I recommend finding a play through on youtube and ONLY WATCHING IT TO THE PART YOU'RE AT!!! Otherwise, the fun isn't there anymore.

Having only played through the main storyline, I really enjoyed it. The beginning tutorial is helpful and the story is good. Portal is still great. It was just meant as a small demo for the source engine, but turned out to be a great little game by itself.
It is a puzzle platform in 1st person, where you have a portal gun, making the solving of puzzles quite unique. You fell really great when you solve the puzzles the first time.

Also, the writing is really wonderful. The main enemy was so great and appreciated by the community, she became an even more impressive antagonist in portal 2.
Even though I have completed this game, I still find myself coming back to it now and then. You can solve the puzzles a little bit different every time. But it is more the atmosphere that keeps you coming back. Yes, it is quite sad and glommy, but it is so clever and interesting that it is fun to try again.

Portal 2 is more of the same, but also great. But this first little game is well worth it, and a good idea to pick up if you have only tried portal 2. Even if you have not.

It works great on most PCs and you don't need a controller. Despite the age I still think this game sounds and looks amazing. The artistic style is solid

Portal is a very innovative game, and if you haven't played it yet, you are definitely missing out on something
Although it is a bit short, it is worth the money

'Fun with physics' probably best describes this game. The portal gun is a fundamentally original game mechanic that will, in the course of half an hour's play, see you flying hundreds of feet and bending the laws of physics (not to mention your own mind). The minimal plot won't bore, letting you focus on the perplexing puzzles and, of course, the famous computer system GLaDOS, superbly voice-acted by Ellen McLain. Basically, imagine if Skynet from the Terminator films had a biting sense of humour. In a video game where you play the only human character you ever encounter, she's a strangely comforting companion.
 Of course, Valve, one of the greatest masters of atmosphere and setting in gaming, create a haunting and frightening game world. If you thought the Black Mesa science facility from Half-Life was scary, the Aperture Science Enrichment Centre is a real nightmare of a place, a soulles labyrinth of terrifying proportions. Look out for telling hints of the facility's degradation scattered throughout the early part of the game. Later, more worrying signs will give you glimpses into the truth of your situation. As you progress, even though you're a silent protagonist, you grow in power and confidence as GLaDOS begins to fear you more and you see exactly what's been going on behind the scenes at Aperture Science...
One thing you will feel, however, is that you wish it had lasted longer. The solution? Get Portal 2.
